summary: Sir Charles Spry was associated with the Australian Security Intelligence Organization (ASIO). The documents indicate that in November 1968, Spry communicated with the Director of Central Intelligence regarding Warren Commission document CD-971. He recommended against its declassification due to concerns related to an investigation of anonymous telephone calls made to the Canberra Embassy both before and after President Kennedy's assassination. The documents consistently refer to Spry's recommendation against declassification of CD-971.
significance: Sir Charles Spry's significance in the JFK assassination context lies in his recommendation against declassifying Warren Commission document CD-971, which pertained to an investigation of anonymous telephone calls to the Canberra Embassy related to the assassination. His recommendation suggests that the information within CD-971 was considered sensitive or potentially damaging to national security or international relations at the time.
